I.  THE ENSUING PROJECT 
1.  The Government of the Kyrgyz Republic is committed to structural reforms to effectively 
manage the transition to sustainable and broad-based economic growth. Policy and institutional 
constraints that need to be addressed include (i) trade and investment competitiveness; (ii) 
development of small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs); (iii) infrastructure development, 
particularly in the energy sector; and (iv) labor productivity. With Asian Development Bank (ADB) 
support since 2008, the Kyrgyz Republic has made significant progress in improving the business 
environment  and  investment  climate,  including  improving  access  to  finance  for  SMEs; 
establishing  an  enabling  policy  and  institutional  framework  for  private  participation  in 
infrastructure; expanding access to new export markets, particularly the European Union, and 
simplifying  institutional  processes  and  guidelines  for  exporters;  streamlining  industry  and 
government  interaction  to  ensure  skills  development  is  in  line  with  market  requirements; 
increasing transparency in government processes, such as procurement; and implementing 
regulations to reduce the cost of doing business and providing incentives to formalize the 
economy.  
 
2.  The proposed Promoting Economic Diversification Program will support the government 
in continuing policy and institutional reforms necessary to increase the private sector’s role in 
economic  development,  including  by  diversifying the  economy  away  from  natural resource 
exploitation  and  remittances-led  consumption.  The  program  is  closely  aligned  with  the 
Sustainable Development Strategy of the Kyrgyz Republic for 2018–20401 and ADB’s country 
partnership strategy with the Kyrgyz Republic.2 It is included in ADB’s country operations and 
business plan, 2018–2020 for the Kyrgyz Republic.3 
 
3.  The reform program will achieve broad-based economic growth. The reform areas are (i) 
trade and investment competitiveness, (ii) SME development, (iii) infrastructure development, and 
(iv) skills development required by industry. The proposed program amount of $60 million will be 
financed in two subprograms of $30 million each, one in November 2019 and the other in 
November 2021, from the Asian Development Fund. 
 
II.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Justification 
 
4.  The transaction technical assistance (TA) will help the government undertake diagnostics 
in the areas of program scope; identify key policy, institutional, and process-related reforms and/or 
interventions; and design their implementation plan. The TA will help identify and implement 
policy, institutional, and related measures to support broad-based economic growth underpinned 
by  increased  trade  and  investment  competitiveness,  SME  development,  infrastructure 
development, and skills development required by industry. It will ensure that the proposed 
program advances the reforms made under the Investment Climate Improvement Programs in 
Kyrgyz Republic.4 TA consultants will prepare the program, focusing on subprogram 1 to ensure 
                                                
1  Government of Kyrgyz Republic. 2018. National Sustainable Development Strategy of the Kyrgyz Republic for 2018–
2040—Taza Koom–Zhany Door (Clean Society–New Era). Bishkek (Draft). 
2  ADB. 2018. Country Partnership Strategy: Kyrgyz Republic, 2018–2022—Supporting Sustainable Growth, Inclusion, 
and Regional Cooperation. Manila. 
3  ADB. 2017. Country Operations Business Plan: Kyrgyz Republic, 2018–2020. Manila. The preliminary design and 
monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
4  ADB. 2015. Completion Report: Investment Climate Improvement Program in the Kyrgyz Republic. Manila; and the 
Second Investment Climate Improvement Program, Subprogram 1 
https://www.adb.org/projects/documents/second-investment-climate-improvement-program-subprogram-1-rrp;

2 
that the ensuing program complies with ADB and government requirements.5 
 
B.  Outputs and Activities 
 
5.  Output  1:  Support  for  improved  trade  and  investment  competitiveness.  The 
consultants  undertake  an  assessment  of  existing  institutional  arrangements  for  trade  and 
investment facilitation, trade-related infrastructure and related capacity (such as logistics centers, 
warehouses, product quality assessment infrastructure, and technical capabilities), and investor 
dispute-resolution mechanisms. The consultants will also assess implementation progress of the 
government’s Strategy for Modernization of National Quality Infrastructure. Based on these 
assessments, the consultants will identify financial and nonfinancial (policy, institutional, process-
related)  interventions  necessary  to  improve  the  Kyrgyz  Republic’s  trade  and  investment 
environment, and develop a 3-year action plan to implement these reforms. 
 
6.  Output 2: Support for more and diversified access of small and medium-sized 
enterprises  to  credit.  The  consultants  will  (i)  review  and  assess  whether  recent  policy 
approaches to address finance supply and demand challenges for SMEs have been successful 
and what aspects require further improvements; (ii) identify policy actions needed to channel more 
financial resources, including private savings, towards SMEs and linking these measures to the 
broader objective of developing the country’s finance sector; and (iii) identify measures to 
maximize the use of technology to strengthen SME access to finance. The consultants will 
develop a 3-year action plan to implement recommended reforms in line with the government’s 
medium-term approach to achieving economic diversification.6 
 
7.  Output  3:  Support  for  development  of  pipeline  of  bankable  public–private 
partnership projects. The consultants will help address the need to develop the country’s public-
private partnership (PPP) program and market through a sound infrastructure project pipeline 
based on project readiness, project viability, and expected development impact, including the 
impact on the economic growth of regions outside the capital. The consultants will review the 
public investment pipeline of the national government and regional governments to identify 
demonstration projects; undertake preliminary technical, financial, economic, legal, institutional, 
social,  and  environmental  due  diligence  (including  compliance  with  ADB’s  safeguards 
requirement) of three to four projects; and prepare project briefs with an overall assessment of 
the viability of PPP structuring. The consultants will also review the business processes and 
operating rules of key PPP institutions and/or entities, including the risk management unit in the 
Ministry of Finance (MOF), the Project Development Support Facility in the Ministry of Economy 
(MOE), and the PPP Council. The consultants will identify institutional and or process-related 
reforms necessary for strengthening the PPP enabling environment and the project pipeline.  
 
8.  Output 4: Support alignment of skills with growth industries’ requirements. The 
consultants will identify the systemic constraints (i.e., policy, institutional, legal and regulatory, 
and financial frameworks) to effectively linking technical and vocational skills to the requirements 
of growth industries, including export-oriented industries. The roles and responsibilities of, and 
coordination among, the National Professional Skills Development Council, the sectoral councils, 
the Agency for Vocational Education, the Skills Development Fund, and the Investment Promotion 
Agency will be assessed. Based on these assessments, the consultants will identify key reforms 
                                                
Subprogram 2 https://www.adb.org/projects/documents/kgz-second-investment-climate-improvement-program-sp2-
rrp; and Subprogram 3 https://www.adb.org/projects/documents/kgz-41544-091-rrp  
5  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 8 October 2018. 
6  Government of Kyrgyz Republic. 2018. Development Program of Kyrgyz Republic for the period 2018–2022 “Unity. 
Trust. Creation”

3 
and interventions needed and develop a 3-year action plan for implementing the recommended 
reforms.  
 
9.  Reforms recommended under the four output areas will be based on a thorough review of 
ongoing government programs in these areas, including those supported by ADB and other 
development partners, to avoid duplication and ensure effective leveraging of the different 
development partners’ support.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
10.  The TA is estimated to cost $550,000, of which $500,000 will be financed on a grant basis 
by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-other sources). The key expenditure items 
are listed in Appendix 1. The government will provide counterpart support in the form of staff, 
office space, venues for training and seminars, office supplies, secretarial assistance, and other 
in-kind contributions. The government was informed that approval of the TA does not commit ADB 
to finance any ensuing project. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
11.  The TA will be implemented from November 2018 to November 2019. The Central and 
West Asia Department, through the Public Management, Financial Sector and Trade Division, will 
select, supervise, and evaluate the consultants’ outputs and procure goods, if applicable. The 
MOE will be the executing agency and the MOE, the MOF, the Ministry of Education and Science, 
and the Investment Promotion Agency will be the implementing agencies. Disbursements will be 
made  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Technical  Assistance  Disbursement  Handbook  (2010,  as 
amended from time to time). The implementation arrangements are summarized in Table 1. 
 
Table 1: Indicative Implementation Arrangements

12.  Consulting services. ADB will engage individual consultants to implement the TA. It is 
estimated that 12 person-months of international consultant services and 13 person-months of 
national consultant services will be required. The multidisciplinary team of consultants will have

4 
expertise in trade and investment advice, finance sector development, SME development, public 
financial management, education and vocational training, economics, law, financial management, 
infrastructure development (including project finance), and social and environment safeguards for 
infrastructure  projects.  Where  necessary,  technical  resource  persons  will  be  recruited  as 
individual consultants. ADB will engage consultants following the ADB Procurement Policy (2017, 
as amended from time to time) and its associated project administration instructions and/or staff 
instructions.7 
 
13.  The consultant requirements for the TA are summarized in Table 2. 
 
Table 2: Summary of Consulting Services Requirement 
Position  Person-months

2. SME finance specialist  3.0

Source: Asian Development Bank. 
 
E.  Governance 
14.  The TA will undertake financial management assessments of relevant government entities 
and propose strengthening measures as needed. It will also conduct preliminary safeguards 
screening (social, environmental, gender, and poverty) of the demonstration PPP projects; carry 
out  required  gender  analyses,  including  collection  of  sex-disaggregated  data;  and  prepare 
documents as needed. 
                                                
7  Terms of Reference for Consultants (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2).
